c74object.name: bach.compl
c74object.digest: Find complement of a pitch-class set
c74object.description: Given a pitch-class set, bach.compl finds its complement, i.e. the set of all the numbers not appearing in the given set.

inlet.digest: Pitch-class set (as a plain list) or tree of pitch-clas sets.

outlet.description: If a tree of pitch-class sets was given, the output is a tree of complement pitch-class sets maintaining the same shape.

objarg.name: modulo
objarg.description: In the standard framework, the modulo is the number of subdivision of the octave (represented as a circle). The modulo is thus the number of points in this circle. The default and most common modulo is 12 (corresponding to semitonal grid). Modulo 24 is the quartertone grid, and so on.

method.name: bang
method.description: Finds the complement of the most recently received input pitch-class set.

method.name: int
method.description:
An integer in the right inlet will set the modulo.
In the standard framework, the modulo is the number of subdivision of the octave (represented as a circle). The modulo is thus the number of points in this circle. The default and most common modulo is 12 (corresponding to semitonal grid). Modulo 24 is the quartertone grid, and so on.

method.name: llll
method.digest: Compute the complement of incoming pitch-class set
method.description: In the first inlet, a pitch-class set, in the form of plain list of numbers (or a tree of such pitch-class sets) will trigger the output of its complement

attribute.name: out
attribute.description:
The out attribute is a sequence of characters identifying the outlet types (one character for each llll outlet). Characters can be one of the following:
n (default): 'native' output: faster and more precise between bach objects, but unreadable by standard Max objects (an "bach.llll" message appears instead).
t: 'text' output: slower and limited in size, but readable by standard Max objects. A plain llll in text format is a generic Max message. To keep the representation invertible (i.e., to allow a bach object receiving a text-format llll to interpret it exactly as if it was native format, except for the size limitation), some specific kinds of symbols are preceded by a backtick: namely, symbols containing parens, or containing textual representations of numbers or pitches, or beginning with a backtick, plus the symbols "null" and "nil" (distinct from the reserved words "null" and "nil" representing the empty list and the empty sublist) are preceded by a backtick. Moreover, the symbols "int", "float" or "list" are preceded by a backtick only if they are the first element of an llll, to distinguish them from the corresponding reserved messages of Max.
m: 'max' output: mostly equivalent to the "t" specifier, but no symbol is backticket except "int", "float" and "list" at the beginning of an llll. It is important to notice that, differently from text-format lllls proper, Max-format lllls might not be invertible even if they do not reach the size limit for Max message. This means that a bach object receiving a Max-format llll output from another bach object might interpret it differently from the original, or in some cases might even reject it.
x: disabled output (nothing is output)
p: 'portal' output: only used by bach.portal to intercept the @out attribute specified while creating the abstraction (see bach.portal).
The native output is recommended, unless communication with standard Max messages is needed. Disabling unused outputs can be useful if extreme optimization of the patch is needed.

c74object.discussion:
In the standard framework, the modulo is the number of subdivision of the octave (represented as a circle). The modulo is thus the number of points in this circle. The default and most common modulo is 12 (corresponding to semitonal grid). Modulo 24 is the quartertone grid, and so on.
A pitch-class set is a plain collection of pitch-classes. A pitch class is nothing but the representative of a set of pitches. Traditionally, it corresponds to the concept of "note", once we abstract it from its octave. For instance, the semitonal framework (when the modulo is 12), all the C belong to the same pitch-class which will be named 0 = {..., C-1, C0, C1, C2, C3, C4, C5, ...}. The pitch-class 1 will be the one containing all C#'s (or Db's); pitch-class 2 will contain all D's, and so on. One will use to name pitch class numbers from 0 to the modulo - 1: indeed, with modulo = 12, pitch-class 12 will coincide with pitch-class 0 (it'll be the C one octave higher). One can thus think at pitch-classes as equally spaced points on a clock, and transposing means rotating them on the clock. A pitch class set is thus represented just by a plain list of pitch classes, such 0 4 7, representing the C major chord. Notice that this coincides with any other representation such as 12 4 19 or 0 -8 -5, but the canonical form, where numbers are from 0 to the modulo-1 is always preferred. Also for pitch-class sets the order of elements is immaterial, and thus 0 4 7 or 4 0 7 or 7 4 0 will all represent the same set. On the other hand a pitch-class (as an abstract concept) can be used to represent things other than pitches, as for instance temporal position in a rhythmic pattern (loop) having a certain number (the modulo) of equally spaced elements.
bach.compl accepts in input also a complex tree of pitch-class sets, and will output the complementary accordingly (preserving the tree shape). For instance, with modulo = 12, the complement of the set [4 7 9] is [0 1 2 3 5 6 8 10 11].

entry.name: Inlet 1 (llll)
entry.description: Pitch-class set (as a plain list) or tree of pitch-clas sets..

entry.name: Outlet 1 (llll)
entry.description: Complement of pitch-class set. If a tree of pitch-class sets was given, the output is a tree of complement pitch-class sets maintaining the same shape.

entry.name: More details
entry.description:
In the standard framework, the modulo is the number of subdivision of the octave (represented as a circle). The modulo is thus the number of points in this circle. The default and most common modulo is 12 (corresponding to semitonal grid). Modulo 24 is the quartertone grid, and so on.
A pitch-class set is a plain collection of pitch-classes. A pitch class is nothing but the representative of a set of pitches. Traditionally, it corresponds to the concept of "note", once we abstract it from its octave. For instance, the semitonal framework (when the modulo is 12), all the C belong to the same pitch-class which will be named 0 = {..., C-1, C0, C1, C2, C3, C4, C5, ...}. The pitch-class 1 will be the one containing all C#'s (or Db's); pitch-class 2 will contain all D's, and so on. One will use to name pitch class numbers from 0 to the modulo - 1: indeed, with modulo = 12, pitch-class 12 will coincide with pitch-class 0 (it'll be the C one octave higher). One can thus think at pitch-classes as equally spaced points on a clock, and transposing means rotating them on the clock. A pitch class set is thus represented just by a plain list of pitch classes, such 0 4 7, representing the C major chord. Notice that this coincides with any other representation such as 12 4 19 or 0 -8 -5, but the canonical form, where numbers are from 0 to the modulo-1 is always preferred. Also for pitch-class sets the order of elements is immaterial, and thus 0 4 7 or 4 0 7 or 7 4 0 will all represent the same set. On the other hand a pitch-class (as an abstract concept) can be used to represent things other than pitches, as for instance temporal position in a rhythmic pattern (loop) having a certain number (the modulo) of equally spaced elements.
bach.compl accepts in input also a complex tree of pitch-class sets, and will output the complementary accordingly (preserving the tree shape). For instance, with modulo = 12, the complement of the set [4 7 9] is [0 1 2 3 5 6 8 10 11].
